instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Hello,

I was wondering if there any schematics or version that will work for this board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)? I'm troubleshooting no power, <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> has 5V. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> has 0.8V. I check for shorts and found none on that line. But without a schematic, I'm a bit lost as to where to go from here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: Never mind. Found it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: Let us know other measurments, once you got the schematic and boardview...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has a short. So going now start trying to isolate.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: is there a way to safely induce power on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> line to see which device gets hot? Was wondering if I pull <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> to isolate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, if this will be fine. Only other option is to start pulling all the parts tied to the line, which are a lot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Post exact value (ohm scale) for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground.
Then check if any big coil has similar value.
If yes, measure ohm value between that coil and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Then you can see if corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted.
If is one from CPU power supply, you can fry the CPU injecting voltage, before removing that MOSFET.

BTW, so many time explained on the forum how to proceed about this issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 1.11
L7231, L7221 and L7211 measure 1.11
Measured from coils to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.71.

So pulled all 3 MOSFET. The coils now measure 1.3. Not much change. Went ahead and replaced all 3 MOSFETs and now I have 20V power but no current draw. None of the big coils have power on them.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is no longer shorted. Readings in the mega ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>, something to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.39
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6
<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_RSLOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_RSLOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> does have about 1.4mV while <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL> has exactly 0. Not sure if this means anything. 
Unfortunately, if it's <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>, I still haven't been able to find replaces or substitutes for this chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
I was thinking reset should be high, like in other old boards.
But in fact, missing "_L" from the end should mean 0V is correct value.
Is the second time when saw this and probably is correct.

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Use SWK000/002 for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> didn't react. I also checked <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>, it too didn't react.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Check PCH's RTC signals at page 12.
Also check <SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

You forgot to post <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> value.
Is <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> powered?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.0
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> - 32Khz

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
"RTC signals at page 12"
There are various!
Look at RTC block of PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Do you mean signals with RTC in the signal name? On page 12, the 3 signals I type were the only RTC signals. But here are all the other RTC signals for the PCH.

<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PCH</SIGNAL> - 1.16
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.0
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 2.5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
PMU (<CHIP>U7800</CHIP>) and T2 chip (<CHIP>U3900</CHIP>) are both involved in the startup sequence.
I didn't get any machine with T2 in my hands yet.
Still need to find all signal levels required.

What about <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PCH_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0

so did some reading on the T2 chip and I?m thinking this board my be bricked. But there is so little info out there regarding T2 chip boards that had parts replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Check some voltages and signals for PMU.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VINRTC_R</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PMU_ACTIVE_READY</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>/RTC
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VINRTC_R</SIGNAL> - 3.39
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL> - 3.36
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.39
<SIGNAL>PMU_ACTIVE_READY</SIGNAL> - 1.8
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> - 1.5
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT</SIGNAL> - 1.8
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.0

also checked <SIGNAL>SOC_XTAL24M_IN</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and only getting 540mV, no signal. Should be 24MHz

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0.0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.39"
So you should have voltage at L7660; check it.

"<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT</SIGNAL> - 1.8"
I think this must be 3V.
In such case, <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> could be bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
@ L7660 - 3.36
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT</SIGNAL> is1.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wondering if there any schematics or sub for this.
threads.message:
Not sure if this means anything, since the customer decided he couldn?t wait any longer, I had to put his computer back together. Upon doing so, I noticed the computer was now pulling current. Most likely charging the battery. But now I can perform NVRAM/PRAM RESET and also power the laptop on/off; in the sense that it stops drawing current. I still doesn?t power up fully.

also found this:

[URL]https://help.apple.com/configurator/mac/2.7.1/#/apd0020c3dc2[/URL]
